awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Manufacturing method for blends of anhydrous probiotic bacteria and low-water, high-fat content nut butters
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the translation of a manufacturing technology to produce a shelf-stable probiotic supplement using peanut and other nut butters.  The availability of probiotics in certain food products has become a major factor in the choice of processed foods by health-conscious consumers. Probiotics in foods may provide a number of benefits, including limiting the growth of pathogenic gut bacteria, reducing bloating, helping to control certain digestive problems such as lactose intolerance, and enhancing nutrient absorption. However, the shelf-life and the need for refrigeration is a major deterrent in the widespread adoption of probiotics food products. Americans consume about 800 million pounds of peanut butter a year and the U.S. market for nut butters totaled $2.3 billion in 2018. The aim of the proposed technology is to define the requirements of providing in nut butters a healthy source of probiotics with a long shelf-life at room temperature. The health benefits from the addition of probiotics to peanut butter and other culinary butters may give these products a competitive advantage.

This I-Corps project is based exploring the translation of a food manufacturing technology to produce nut butters with probiotics. This manufacturing method uses blends of anhydrous probiotic bacteria and low-water activity, high-fat content culinary butters made from roasted nuts. Typically, a slurry is made from freeze-dried probiotic bacteria and edible oil, which is subsequently blended into a warm nut butter at the time of the addition of melted structuring fat and before fat crystallization and product packaging. Dispersing and storing probiotics in such an anhydrous fatty food environment helps keep probiotic bacteria viable for a longer time at room temperature. Long-term viability of probiotic bacteria was tested over a 12-month period by measuring the number of colony-forming units (CFU) from the different bacteria stored at 4 oC and 20 oC in multiple low-water activity, fat-based foods including peanut butter, anhydrous butterfat, and palm fat. Room temperature-stable probiotics products do not require refrigeration during shipping or storage. Eliminating cold storage in the value chain is important for both consumer pricing and sales convenience.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcome Report (Award#2039443)

The recent focus on microbiome studies has confirmed the critical role played by the gut biome for improved general health and specifically gastrointestinal health. A multiplicity of freeze-dried probiotic bacterial species is available commercially and are the primary source of probiotics in food products. However, a major impediment to growth for the industry is the limited shelf life due to the limited viability of these health-promoting bacteria in most food products.

Our project aims to introduce a healthy source of probiotics in nut butters with long shelf-life at room temperature. Our patented probiotics technology is a new formulation which utilizes a novel manufacturing method for healthy culinary butters and spreads made from blends of anhydrous probiotic bacteria and low water activity, high-fat content nut butters.

Our PB’N’Yay team consisted of two entrepreneurial leads, one technical lead and one mentor. The team conducted 100 interviews with potential customers to understand the need for such product and the commercial viability of this technology. Two key customer segments were identified – i) B2C – where current probiotics users and health-conscious consumers were identified as the potential customer segment; and ii) B2B – where probiotic food manufacturing companies and nut butter manufacturers were considered another segment.

The team conducted several interviews in the B2C segment and realized quickly that it’s difficult to understand the need from the consumer segment without spending a lot of time to conduct multiple interviews. Instead, we pivoted to understand the probiotic need and trend from the probiotic food manufacturers. Some of the key findings were: i) consumers don’t like to take probiotic pill as it may give them a perception of being sick; ii) There aren’t many sources of probiotic for vegans and people who are allergic to dairy products. Probiotic food industries have limitations in terms of what they can offer as probiotic source since probiotics are not viable at room temperature for a long time and there’s only one kind of probiotics available in spore form (which remains viable for longer period comparatively). After conducting multiple interviews in this segment, the team concludes that probiotic food manufacturers can expand their product range by using our patented technology as well as decrease their manufacturing cost by incorporating lower amount of probiotic (since viability doesn’t go down quickly using this new technology).

The interviews with the other B2B segment, nut butter manufacturers also provided the team good insights. Nut butter manufacturers look for expanding their product range and this technology does present a good opportunity for them. However, such manufacturers have introduced functional nut butter products in the past without much success hence they are hesitant in adopting this technology.

Additionally, the team learned the entire value chain or the ecosystem which is needed to introduce a functional food product in the market. The team has been exploring a licensing strategy to partner with probiotic supplier, probiotic food manufacturers or nut butter manufacturers in order to get the probiotic nut butter to the market.


Last Modified: 04/13/2021
Modified by: Rebecca Menapace
